results.notes:
Thallus continuous-areolate, whitish overall, mottled with olive-green or olive-brown. Prothallus not prominent but appears to be whitish. Apothecia common, small (<0.2 mm diam), immersed, black and epruinose.

Micro: Epihymenium brown. Hymenium short, measured 56 and 71 um in different places. Didn’t get a great look at paraphyses, but they appear to be non-moniliform or submoniliform. Some or all appear to have 1+ round apical cells. Epinecral layer visible above cortex. Conidia short, 5-7 um, though measurement precision pretty low.

Spores hyaline, simple, ovoid to subglobose, 5 measured: 11×5.4, 10.2×8.3, 11.5×7.1, 11×7, 10.5×6.3, 14×7.5, 11.6×6.9, 11.4×7.1 micrometers. Thin-walled. 8 spores per ascus.

Chemistry: Thallus medulla locally K+R (norstictic acid crystals) in several places in sections.

On siliceous cement sandstone in chaparral, ~800 m elevation

results.notes:
Growing abundantly in hardwood leaf-litter near Quercus spp., Fagus grandifolia, Acer spp., Carpinus caroliniana, Platanus occidentalis and Lindera benzoin. On a moist slope near the edge of a stream. Odor not distinctive. Basal mycelium white, growing rapidly and anastomosing with the basal mycelium of other stems while the specimens were refrigerated. Stems pruinose. Caps smooth with translucent-striate margins, hygrophanous. Young gills white, becoming pink with spores. Gills adnexed. Clamps absent in all tissues. Pileipellis a cutis with encrusting pigment. Pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (28.2) 30.3 – 39.5 (40.8) × (8.5) 8.9 – 10.7 (11.3) µm, Q = (2.8) 3.2 – 4 (4.3); N = 30, Me = 35.4 × 9.7 µm; Qe = 3.7. Spores angular with 6-7 major angles. Spore measurements: (8.9) 9.7 – 11.1 (11.5) × (5.7) 6.1 – 6.9 (7.7) µm, Q = (1.4) 1.5 – 1.7 (1.9); N = 30, Me = 10.3 × 6.5 µm; Qe = 1.6.

results.notes:
On the ground, with conifer debris, shortly after snow melt about 5,500 feet.
For quite some time I though this could be Peziza, with the recurved edges, etc.
2 cms to 6 cms, shallow cup shaped, dark brown, with a minute stipe a little fluted.
Ascospores ellipsoid, nonapiculate, with isolated warts. With a drop of water, they were opaque, so I couldn’t observe them to be biguttulate. Initially the spores measured (8.6-9.5) x (5.2-5.5), I thought that they were a little dry… justifying to be small, but with a drop of alcohol they got too big and couldn’t see the warts, like they just swell up.

results.notes:
In the woods, mostly Douglas fir, on moss, in a humid area in early spring.
Cap 3.5 cms, orange, margin inrolled, moist. Gills white, close, decurrent. Stipe orange, widening to a bulbous base with tomentum.

I had a little trouble separating this one from the others. The spores don’t appear to be lacrymate, and q=1.62 is less elongated than C squamulosa. On moss, stipe widening, and small size, hopefully separates it from Bonomyces.

results.notes:
Growing singly in soil among hardwood leaf litter on a ridge top near Quercus spp., Carya spp., Liriodendron tulipifera, Acer spp. and likely other small hardwoods. Stem silvery gray, fibrillose striate and twisted. Cap umbonate, smooth and finely fibrillose with translucent-striate margin. Gills sinuate and pale gray when young, becoming pinkish brown. Some gills intervenose. Clamps lacking in all tissues. Pileipellis a transition between a cutis and a trichoderm. Pileipellis elements with brown intracellular pigment. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia hyaline, narrowly conical to fusiform to lageniform, some with secondary septa or partially encrusted with crystalline material. Cheilocystidia measurements: (43.8) 44.6 – 68 (71.4) × (9.3) 11.3 – 14.9 (16.5) µm, Q = (3.6) 3.7 – 4.9 (5.3); N = 10, Me = 57.2 × 13.1 µm; Qe = 4.4. Basidia 1-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (28) 28.1 – 35.6 × (7.2) 9.9 – 12.3 (12.8) µm, Q = (2.4) 2.43 – 3.3 (3.9); N = 12, Me = 32 × 11.1 µm; Qe = 2.9. Spores many-angled. Spore measurements: (11.2) 12.4 – 16.5 (18.1) × (6.6) 6.9 – 9.4 (9.9) µm, Q = (1.5) 1.6 – 2 (2.1); N = 30, Me = 14.3 × 8 µm; Qe = 1.8.

results.notes:
Thallus varying from squamulose-imbricated, gray green to other parts of thallus (assuming it’s the same thing) shiny, darker green to black-green, convex squamules. Parts of thallus whitish (epinecral layer?). Aps black, flat to convex, largest measured ~1.5 mm diam. Larger aps often with some whitish pruina (?). Micro: Thallus cortex measured in two areas, 35-45 um thick with ~15 um upper (epinecral?) layer. Apothecia with epithecium including purple-pigmented areas that become more apparent after K treatment. Parathecium yellowish.

Spores: 27×3.5, 28×5.2, 28×4.5, 19×5.3 um. (sample of larger-sized spores, smaller also present). Many spores with 3 clear septations, others with 4-5 (though those are harder to see), some with fewer than 3. Generally bacilliform with obtuse ends.

Epithecium K+V (I think) N+reddish-purple. However, you can see purple in the epithecium pre-treatment, and part of me thinks both acids are mainly just making this more visible. No pigments leaking out of epithecium.

On serpentine outcrop among chaparral, ~730 m elevation.

results.notes:
Growing singly in sand on the bank of a stream. Quercus spp., Fagus grandifolia, Acer spp., Carpinus caroliniana, Platanus occidentalis and Lindera benzoin present nearby. Stipe smooth. Cap with translucent-striate margin and depressed center. Gills short-decurrent, white when young and not marginate. Clamps absent in the lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia present, hyaline, thin-walled, scattered on gill edge; oblong ellipsoid, sphaeropedunculate or clavate. Cheilocystidia measurements: (15.8) 17.7 – 25.9 (28.1) × (6.5) 7.3 – 12.1 (12.8) µm, Q = (1.4) 1.7 – 2.6 (3.3); N = 25, Me = 21 × 10 µm; Qe = 2.2. Basidia mostly 4-sterigmate, some 2-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (21.2) 23.9 – 30.2 (31.4) × (7.3) 7.7 – 10.4 (10.6) µm, Q = (2.3) 2.5 – 3.4 (3.9); N = 16, Me = 26.8 × 9.1 µm; Qe = 3. Spores with 5-6 angles. Spore measurements: (8.2) 8.6 – 9.9 (10.4) × (6.4) 6.6 – 7.7 (8.3) µm, Q = (1.1) 1.2 – 1.4 (1.6); N = 30, Me = 9.3 × 7.2 µm; Qe = 1.3.

results.notes:
Growing scattered in the sand of a stream bed. Quercus spp., Fagus grandifolia, Acer spp., Carpinus caroliniana, Platanus occidentalis and Lindera benzoin present nearby. Stems smooth and gray. Basal mycelium white and thin. Caps hygrophanous, grayish brown and finely fibrillose. Gills adnate and white when young, not marginate. Clamps absent in all tissues or at least not observed. Pileipellis a cutis. Pileipellis hyphae up to 22 µm wide. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia hyaline, thin-walled, lageniform to tibiiform, some flexuouse. Basidia 2-sterigmate to 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (19.5) 24.5 – 32.4 (36.2) × (7.3) 7.9 – 9.7 (11) µm, Q = (1.9) 2.6 – 3.8 (4.2); N = 25, Me = 28.8 × 8.9 µm; Qe = 3.3. Spores with 7-9 angles. Spore measurements: (7.8) 8.7 – 11 (11.4) × (4.8) 5.1 – 6.3 (6.6) µm, Q = (1.3) 1.5 – 1.9 (2.2); N = 30, Me = 9.8 × 5.8 µm; Qe = 1.7.

Datos de Yopal, registrado en Bosque Seco Tropical (temporada de lluvia). Precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, Precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio. con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%). cuenta con una altura sobre el nivel del mar entre 0 y 1000 m, una pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, como se referencia en DANE. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas. (Bustamante et al., 2017; DANE, 1999; Castro y Sosa, 2017).

Son comunes plantas representativas como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.
results.location_name: Yopal, Casanare, Colombia

Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas. (Bustamante et al., 2017; DANE, 1999; Castro y Sosa, 2017).

Son comunes plantas representativas como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.
results.location_name: Yopal, Casanare, Colombia

results.notes:
Datos de Yopal, registrado en Bosque Seco Tropical (temporada de lluvia). Precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, Precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio. con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%). cuenta con una altura sobre el nivel del mar entre 0 y 1000 m, una pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, como se referencia en DANE. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas. (Bustamante et al., 2017; DANE, 1999; Castro y Sosa, 2017).

Son comunes plantas representativas como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.

Recomendaciones: los registros y las descripciones que hagas, te permitirán determinar el ejemplar:

-Tomar fotografías de las diferentes estructuras del basidioma/ascoma/cuerpo fructifero/carpoforo/seta (por encima, por debajo y de perfil), su estipe, pileo y base, en el caso de retirar el ejemplar sin conocerlo, debes comprometerte a realizar una descripción detallada para aportar a su conocimiento y que no quede en una muestra arrancada, fotografiada y desechada. Además de retirarlo con sustrato para conocer otras características de la base del basidioma.

-Es importante que describas las dimensiones (altura y diametro), forma, consistencia, textura, color y olor. Recuerda que los ejemplares cambian bastante según su estado de desarrollo, así que es ideal familiarizarse con la zona y temporada en la que crecen, para hacer un seguimiento y logres observar la variabilidad fenotípica del basidioma o ascoma (cuerpo fructífero).

-Toma fotos del entorno y agrega datos del ecosistema (humedad, temperatura, altura, tipo de bosque, insectos asociados, etc).

-No olvides que la determinación de macromicetos es compleja y no se realiza únicamente con fotografías, esta tarea (a nivel de género y especie; en la mayoría) implica actividades de descripción morfológica externa e interna, esporada, reacciones químicas, microscopia e incluso herramientas moleculares (ADN/PCR).

results.notes: On sandstone and seemingly on lichens over sandstone. Not really obviously parasitic though. Thallus lacking or very scant grey. Apothecia up to 0.8mm, nestled in and about Physconia and other lichens, sparse, plane, with a persistently raised orange rim that is often folded or somewhat flexuose. Proper margin dominant, thalline margin reduced to absent. Hymenium 95-105µm (with epi) and hypothecium hyaline. Exciple C+R, Epihymenium C-. Paraphyses thin, not branched?, scarcely widened at tip, often with an epihymenial crystal. Spores polarilocular, narrowly ellipsoid, expanded at middle. Average size: 17.2×5.1×3.5 (n=4).

results.notes: On twigs and trunk bark of Baccharis pilularis shrub on coastal bluff. Thallus white to yellowish orange, thin and coagulating into tiny yellow areoles. Apothecia originating sessile, yellow, with a thick rim, becoming sessile, plane, epruinose, with a raised rim that is lighter orange than the disk, ultimately disappearing, without grey outer thalline rim. Exciple mostly lacking algae, which is present at corners of base of apothecia. Exciple and epihymenium C-. Paraphyses thin, simple and unbranched, at times with an expanded apical cell. Spore average size: 11.8×4.7×4.0 (n=6). Seems a better fit at C. californica than C. pyracea.

results.notes:
Growing among moss on the trunk of a live Tsuga canadensis. Stems and Caps glabrous. Gills white and adnexed. Caulocystidia cylindrical to clavate, hyaline or with brown intracellular pigment. Pileipellis a cutis. Pileipellis hyphae with brown intracellular pigment. Subpellis composed of rounded cells. Pileocystidia absent or at least rare. All lamellar structures inamyloid. Clamps present in the lamellar trama and stipe trama. Pleurocystidia hyaline, conical to utriform to lageniform. Pleurocystidia measurements: (45.6) 51.5 – 97.1 (99.5) × (8.2) 8.9 – 17.6 (22.6) µm, Q = (3.2) 3.4 – 6.7 (7.1); N = 13, Me = 65.3 × 13.8 µm; Qe = 4.9. Cheilocystidia similar to pleurocystidia but smaller. Cheilocystidia measurements: 29.4 – 46.9 × (7.3) 7.31 – 9 µm, Q = 3.3 – 6.4; N = 2, Me = 38.1 × 8.2 µm; Qe = 4.8. Basidia (1) 2-sterigmate to 4-sterigmate. Spores smooth, hyaline and weakly amyloid. Spore measurements: (6.9) 7.7 – 10.1 (10.5) × (3.9) 4.4 – 5.8 (6.4) µm, Q = (1.4) 1.6 – 1.9 (2.2); N = 30, Me = 8.7 × 4.9 µm; Qe = 1.8.

results.notes:
Growing abundantly on decorticated portions of a fallen Carya ovata trunk. Synnemata gelatinous and producing conidia toward the apices. All hyphae simple-septate. Hyphae in base of synnemata amyloid. Conidiophores hyaline. Conidiogenesis blastic. Conidia hyaline, smooth, hemi-circinate and 3-septate at maturity. Conidia measurements: (7.8) 8.6 – 10.6 (10.8) × (6) 6.4 – 7.4 (8) µm, Q = 1.2 – 1.5 (1.6); N = 30, Me = 9.5 × 7 µm; Qe = 1.4. Stipitate pseudothecia/apothecia present among the synnemata that may represent the teleomorph. Pseudothecia also with a base of amyloid sterile hyphae. Apex of stipe containing unitunicate, thick-walled, 8-spored asci and hyaline pseudoparaphyses. Asci measurements: (44.5) 46.5 – 62.4 (66.3) × (6.4) 6.9 – 8.7 (10) µm, Q = (5.1) 5.8 – 7.8 (8.1); N = 20, Me = 54.1 × 8 µm; Qe = 6.8. Ascospores smooth, hyaline and 0-septate to 1-septate. Ascospore measurements: (7.2) 7.8 – 13.3 (13.5) × (2.4) 2.6 – 3.2 (3.4) µm, Q = (2.3) 2.7 – 4.9 (5.1); N = 24, Me = 10.9 × 2.9 µm; Qe = 3.8.

results.notes:
Macro: no thallus to speak of, though some apothecia have a bit of gray below them. Apothecia burnt orange in color with lighter orange rim (proper exciple), rims thin and +/- flush with disc. Aps plane becoming convex with age. Largest aps ~0.6 mm diam. Aps fairly clustered together.

Micro: hymenium ~75 um, subhymenium ~60 um. Exciple seems composed of elongate hyphae. Thick, continuous algal layer beneath exciple.

Spores polarilocular, ellipsoid, hyaline. 3 measured: 14×6, 15×6, and 16×6 micrometers. Spore septa average 2.9 um (n=16), largest measured ~3.8 micrometers.

Chemistry: Thallus cortex K+V, epihymenium and proper exciple C+reddish-purple

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1374/2021_P1000116 and Bot_1377/2021_DSC3261

Habitat: mixed wood (Fagus sylvatica, Picea abies, Fraxinus ornus, Ostrya carpinifolia dominant trees) on moderately steep mountain slope, south aspect; calcareous ground; in shade, relatively warm place; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevations 610 m (2.000 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: moss on 0.5 – 1.5 cm thick layer of humus on calcareous rock half-buried in ground.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča; between villages Soča and Trenta; near the trail from abandoned farmhouse Strgulc, Soča 47 to Planina Na skalah, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: There are only a few records of this species in Slovenia (Ref. 5., Ref. 6.). Most of them are not far from this find. The thallus of this find was sterile. So, characteristic, almost black apothecia shaped as upright painted nails could not be used in the determination. This make my determination somewhat uncertain. However, small (up to 3 cm long and 0.8 – 1.5 cm wide), mostly concave, +/- shiny, only moderately bullate lobes, some minutely pruinose near the margins (hard to see when the thallus is moist); lobes have distinct bluish-black tint except in a completely dry state (eventually, when soaked with rain, slightly bluish-green-black); whitish under side with broad, dark brown to black and flat veins and few, dark, stubby and short rhizines speak in favor of Peltigera neckeri. The thallus was about 20 cm in diameter and firmly adpressed to the substrate and interwoven with the moss. It was difficult to separate the thallus from the substrate. The thallus had mostly non-overlapping lobes and on some places appeared like reduced to scattered lobes.

Camera. Panasonic, Lumix G91, G-Vario 1:3.5-5.6/12-60 ASPH and Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8
results.location_name: Lower Trenta Valley, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes: Outside of the Northeast corner of Kottman Hall. Growing under the soil at the base of a Tilia sp. Quercus rubra nearby. Ascocarp had been excavated and partially eaten by a Sciurus carolinensis. Strong pungent odor. Peridium verrucose, reddish-brown when young, becoming blackish. All structures inamyloid. Asci thick-walled and 4-spored. Spores brown with alveolate reticulation. Spore measurements: (27.6) 28.5 – 33.5 (35.5) × (19.3) 21.3 – 23.8 (27.7) µm, Q = (1.1) 1.2 – 1.5 (1.7); N = 30, Me = 30.7 × 22.9 µm; Qe = 1.4. Alveoli measurements: (2.5) 2.9 – 4.9 (6.3) × (2.2) 2.5 – 3.5 (3.9) µm, Q = (1) 1.1 – 1.5 (1.8); N = 30, Me = 3.9 × 3 µm; Qe = 1.3.

results.notes:
In damp moss; mixed woods, hardwoods, hemlock.
Cheilocystidia numerous, clavate to subventricose, with slightly swollen apex to subcapitate to capitate.
Pleurocystidia absent (none observed).
Caulocystidia observed near apex of stipe, but none found below the upper 10% of stipe; cylindric, flexuous, subcapitate.
No pileocystidia found.
Spores subrhomboid with subacute apex in side view. Fairly prominent depression (indicative of plage) seen in favorably profiled examples. Some observed with “ears” (calyptrate). Slightly verrucose. Dimensions 10-11 × 5-7.
The only thing that appears to not fit the subcerina concept is that caulocystidia were observed only near the apex of the stipe; absent from the rest of the stipe.

results.notes:
Growing mostly from moss/algae covered stones (!) lodged in soil bank. Also appears to be on exposed part of buried wood. Hyphae without clamps. Thin, cobweb like hyphae covers the substrate. Pileus and lamellae edge appear pruinose under handlens. Many cuadrate crystals in hymenium. Filiforme cheilocystidia present solitary or in tufts. Red guttation present and hymenium seems to turn pinkish with age, but unknown whether this is due to spores or character of the flesh. Resilient, lasting over a week without much decay.

results.notes: Very young Allotropa virgata. Gifford Pinchot National Forest, WA, USA 6/4/21. This mycoheterotrophic plant parasitizes the mycelium of Western Matsutake(Tricholoma murrillianum). This area is one of my favorite harvest sites for Matsutake in the Fall(Oct.-Dec). If one encounters Allotropa virgata in Spring/early summer it is always a good practice to make note and return to said location the next Fall to harvest Matsutake. I’ve used this method for many years and look forward to and enjoy photographing both species here annually.

results.notes:
Growing in soil on the edge of a trail near Quercus spp., Acer spp., Fagus grandifolia, Carpinus caroliniana and Tsuga canadensis were present nearby. Cap smooth and hygrophanous, 1.7 cm wide. Gills free. Stem 4.5 cm long, with white basal mycelium. Clamps absent absent in the pileipellis and lamellar trama. Pileipellis elements with brown intracellular pigment. Pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (24) 25.4 – 32.8 (34.6) × (10.6) 11 – 12.6 (13) µm, Q = (2) 2.2 – 2.8 (3); N = 30, Me = 28.9 × 11.8 µm; Qe = 2.5. Spores pink in mass. Spores cruciform. Spore measurements: (8.4) 9.1 – 11.3 (11.8) × (8) 8.4 – 10 (10.8) µm, Q = 1 – 1.2 (1.3); N = 30, Me = 10.1 × 9.3 µm; Qe = 1.1.

results.notes:
I think this observation shows the same species as each of obs 417729 and obs 368060. The spores seen in this present observation (06-05-2021) appear to misshapen, possibly due to spore walls collapsing? The two linked observations show examples of what I suspect are abnormal spores (417729) and normal spores (368060) for the same species.
Hoping to find a few more of these. The one documented here was well past maturity; I did not attempt to scope anything other than spores. Spore drop thin, appearing to be slightly pigmented.

results.notes:
Many fruit bodies at various stages of maturity observed growing on either wood or from buried woody debris.
Here is the reason why I cannot in good conscience recommend K. marginellus as an edible, obs 454494.

results.notes:
Fruiting in groups in needle duff under closely grouped white pines. Small black cherry and maple just beyond the perimeter of the pines.

Examined spores from print at 400x; 10 different locations of print in a Congo red mount and 5 different locations in a cotton blue mount. Spore dimensions consistently ranged 6.5-7.5 × 4-5, with most widths around 4.5. One spore seen in these 15 mounts slightly exceeded 8 microns in length.

results.notes: Fruiting bodies were firmly attached to decaying wood branches against sand next to a stream in heavy brush with partial shade. The blackish-brown outer texture is tough and felt-like. The interior is gelatinous rubber but soon becoming watery, without smell or taste. The images were first identified as a Galiella sp by the Center For Mushroom Research in Chiang Mai, Thailand. I am interested in what features seen within these images bring a name change.
